Person, firm, corporation, or association , as used herein, includes the following: any person, firm, corporation or association which owns any such machine; the person, firm, corporation, or association in whose place of business any such machine is placed for use by the public; and the person, firm, corporation, or association having control over such machine; provided, however, that the payment of such fee by any person, firm, corporation or association enumerated herein shall be deemed a compliance with this article. ( Ord. No. 02-93, § 1, 5-4-1993 ) Sec. 17-85. - Penalty. Unless stated otherwise, violations of this article are punishable as provided in section 1-7. ( Ord. No. 02-93, § 11, 5-4-1993 ) Sec. 17-86. - Seizure and destruction of machine. If the chief of police shall have reason to believe any mechanical amusement device is used as a gambling device, such machine may be seized by the police and impounded and, if upon trial the exhibitor is found guilty, such machine shall be destroyed by the police. ( Ord. No. 02-93, § 10, 5-4-1993 ) Sec. 17-87. - Gambling devices not permitted. Nothing in this article shall in any way be construed to authorize, license or permit any gambling devices whatsoever, or any mechanism that has been judicially determined to be a gambling device, or in any way contrary to law, or that may be contrary to any future laws of the state. ( Ord. No. 02-93, § 2, 5-4-1993 ) Sec. 17-88. - Prohibitions and restrictions. No person holding a license under this article shall permit persons under 18 years of age to play or operate any mechanical amusement device as defined in section 17-84, unless there is present on the premises an adult over 21 years of age, and no such business shall permit the use of said mechanical amusement device to be operated between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. ( Ord. No. 02-93, § 8, 5-4-1993 ) Secs. 17-89—17-119. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - LICENSE
Sec. 17-120. - Required. Any person displaying for public patronage or keeping for operation any mechanical amusement device as herein defined by section 17-84 shall be required to obtain a license from the city, upon payment of a license fee. Application for such license shall be made to the city upon a form to be supplied by the city clerk for that purpose. ( Ord. No. 02-93, § 3, 5-4-1993 ) Sec. 17-121. - Application. The application for such license shall contain the following information: (1) Name and address of the applicant, age, date and place of birth. (2) Prior convictions of applicant, if any. (3) Place where machine or device is to be displayed or operated and the business conducted at that place. (4) Description of machine to be covered by the license, mechanical features, name of manufacturer, and serial number. No license shall be issued to any applicant unless he shall be over 21 years of age and a citizen of the United States. ( Ord. No. 02-93, § 4, 5-4-1993 ) Sec. 17-122. - Inspection. The application for a license shall be made out in duplicate, with one copy being referred to the city building inspector. (1) The city building inspector shall inspect all wiring and connections to the machine, and all sanitary facilities in the building and determine if the same complies with the electrical and building code of the city, and shall either recommend or not recommend the application. (2) No license shall be issued to any applicant unless recommended by the city building inspector and approved by city council. ( Ord. No. 02-93, § 5, 5-4-1993 ) Sec. 17-123. - Display of license. (a) The license herein provided for shall be posted permanently and conspicuously at the location of the machine in the premises wherein the device is to be operated or maintained to be operated. (b) A license shall not be transferable from person to person nor place to place, (unless approved by city council) and shall be usable only at the place and by the person designated in the license. ( Ord. No. 02-93, § 7, 5-4-1993 ) Sec. 17-124. - Revocation of license. Every license issued under this division is subject to the right, which is hereby expressly reserved, to revoke the same should the licensee, directly or indirectly, permit the operation of any mechanical amusement device contrary to the provisions of this article, the ordinances of the city, or the law of the state. Said license may be revoked by the city council after written notice to the licensee, which notice shall specify the ordinance or law violations with which the licensee is charged, if after a hearing the licensee is found to be guilty of such violations. Ten days' notice of the hearing shall be given the licensee. At such hearing the licensee and his attorney may present and submit evidence and witnesses in his defense. ( Ord. No. 02-93, § 9, 5-4-1993 ) Secs. 17-125—17-146. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - FRANCHISE FEES DIVISION 1. - CABLE OR VIDEO FRANCHISE FEE[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- State Law reference— Franchising of cable and video services, O.C.G.A. § 36-76-1 et seq.
Sec. 17-147. - Franchise fee for state-issued cable or video franchise. The city hereby requires a franchise fee of five percent of gross revenues generated within the city for any cable or video state franchise issued within its corporate boundaries by the state. ( Ord. No. 2008-01, § 1, 1-22-2008 ) Sec. 17-148. - Authorized designee. The city hereby authorizes the mayor or manager, upon receipt of notice to the city of its right to designate a franchise fee for an applicant for or holder of an existing state franchise, to provide written notice to the Secretary of State and each applicant for or holder of a state franchise within a service area that is wholly or partially located within the city limits of the five percent franchise fee rate applicable to such applicant or holder of a state franchise. ( Ord. No. 2008-01, § 2, 1-22-2008 ) DIVISION 2. - TELEGRAPH AND/OR TELEPHONE FRANCHISES RATE
Sec. 17-149. - Due compensation for telephone companies with end user retail customers within the city. (a) The city hereby requires due compensation of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues, as defined in paragraphs (8) and (9) of subsection (b) of O.C.G.A. § 46-5-1; provided, however, that any company which pays in excess of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues pursuant to an existing franchise agreement shall continue to pay in accordance with the agreement until the expiration of the franchise agreement or December 31, 2012, whichever occurs first, and any company which pays in excess of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues in accordance with an occupational license tax arrangement shall continue to pay in accordance with such payment schedule until December 31, 2012. (b) Regarding any telephone company that does not have retail, end user customers located within the city's municipal boundaries, the payment by such company to a municipal authority in accordance with the rates set by regulations promulgated by the department of transportation for the use of its rights of way shall be considered the payment of due compensation. ( Ord. No. 2009-08, § 2, 11-10-2009 ) Sec. 17-150. - Authorized designee. The city manager, or his designee, shall, on behalf of the city, exercise day-to-day administrative duties necessary to fulfill the regulatory authority of the city under O.C.G.A. § 46-5-1, et seq. and shall perform the following duties: (1) Review application information submitted by a telephone company to the city and, if an application is incomplete, notify the telegraph or telephone company within 15 business days of the receipt of such application, identifying in such notice all application deficiencies. (2) Report the receipt of a completed application to the council within 60 calendar days of the receipt of such completed application. (3) Review payments of due compensation submitted by the company to ensure compliance with the provisions of the amended law and this section. (4) Provide a coordination function between a telephone company and all city departments on any matter relating to the amended law and this section. (5) Arrange and evaluate, no more than once a year, a comprehensive review of the records of a company which is reasonably related to the calculation and payment of due compensation. (6) Provide to all telegraph and telephone companies located in its rights of way written notice of annexations and changes in municipal corporate boundaries. ( Ord. No. 2009-08, § 3, 11-10-2009 ) Secs. 17-151—17-175. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - GARAGE SALES[5]
Footnotes: --- (5) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1(a)—(e), adopted Nov. 22, 2010 , added provisions that were not specifically amendatory. At the editor's discretion, said provisions were included as §§ 17-176—17-180.
Sec. 17-176. - Definition. [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] Garage sale means the sale or trading of clothing, furniture, household items, dishes, antiques or similar goods or merchandise, other than in the normal course of business, or the sale or trading of such goods, as outlined in this definition, by a person not regularly engaged in such business. Such goods or merchandise do not need to be attended for a sale to be deemed to be in existence. "Garage sale" shall include "yard sales," "carport sales," "rummage sales" and similar types of sales or events. ( Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1(a), 11-22-2010 ) Sec. 17-177. - Number and duration. Garage sales shall be allowed not more than four times in any calendar year for any premises. No sale may run more than two consecutive days. ( Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1(b), 11-22-2010 ) Sec. 17-178. - Display area. All displays of garage sale merchandise shall be limited to that portion of the property which is at least five feet back from the property line on all sides, and at least ten feet back from any curb or road edge. ( Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1(c), 11-22-2010 ) Sec. 17-179. - Signage requirements. Signs advertising a garage sale may be placed seven days prior to the sale and must be removed not later than 48 hours upon completion of the sale, and any temporary signage must be otherwise consistent with App. A, § 4.44.7 of the Springfield Municipal Code. Each garage sale sign shall include the date(s) of the sale and the street address of the sale. No signs pertaining to the garage sale shall be placed on public property, nor in any median, nor in any public right-of-way. Signs may be placed on private property only with the consent of the property owner. ( Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1(d), 11-22-2010 ) Sec. 17-180. - Prohibited acts. No individual, firm, corporation or other partnership shall be permitted to engage in the business of promoting or conducting garage sales for others for a fee or other consideration. ( Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1(e), 11-22-2010 ) Sec. 17-181. - Permission of property owner. Where a garage sale is held upon a premises by any individual, organization, or group which does not own said premises, the party conducting the garage sale shall obtain written permission by the owner of the premises, naming the party conducting the sale; and the owner's express permission to the conduct the sale; and the date and time when the sale shall commence; and the date and time when the sale shall conclude; and the physical address of the premises upon which the sale shall be conducted; and the signature of the owner. The party conducting the sale shall keep this written permission on site and in his or her possession throughout the duration of the garage sale and shall produce the same to any city official, city officer, or law enforcement officer who requests it for review. ( Ord. No. 2011-01, § 1(f), 1-11-2011 ) Sec. 17-182. - Limitations. Garage sales or yard sales are limited to residential property. (Ord. No. 2012-12 , 6-26-2012) Sec. 17-183. - Exemptions. Bona fide charitable and non-profit civic organizations shall be exempt from the rules set forth in this article, however, upon request shall provide the proper documentation. (Ord. No. 2012-12 , 6-26-2012)

div.head: Chapter 18 - MUNICIPAL COURT
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - RESERVED
Secs. 18-1—18-50. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - RESERVED
Secs. 18-51—18-75. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - OFFICE OF PROSECUTING ATTORNEY OF THE MUNICIPAL COURT
Sec. 18-76. - Short title. This article shall be known as the "Ordinance Establishing the Office of Prosecuting Attorney of the Municipal Court of the City of Springfield." (Ord. No. 2016-01 , 4-12-2016) Sec. 18-77. - Findings and intent. This ordinance is adopted to address requirements made under Georgia law for the city to pass an ordinance or resolution creating the office of prosecuting attorney of the municipal court should the city choose to hire or have a prosecuting attorney of the municipal court. Under state law, in order to have a municipal court prosecutor, the city must pass this ordinance or resolution and provide to the Prosecuting Attorneys' Council of the State of Georgia a copy of the same. The city is also required to submit the name of the person(s) appointed to be the prosecuting attorney of the municipal court within 30 days of such appointment. It is therefore the intent of the city to comply with Georgia law, particularly Article 5, of Chapter 18, of Title 15 of the Official Code of Georgia, Annotated, and to enact this article. (Ord. No. 2016-01 , 4-12-2016) Sec. 18-78. - Establishment of office. The office of prosecuting attorney of the municipal court of the City of Springfield is hereby established for the purpose of providing representation of the City of Springfield in the prosecution of matters which are within the jurisdiction of the municipal court of the City of Springfield. The position of prosecuting attorney for the municipal court shall be a part time position. (Ord. No. 2016-01 , 4-12-2016) Sec. 18-79. - Qualifications. Any person appointed as the prosecuting attorney for the municipal court of the City of Springfield shall be a member in good standing of the State Bar of Georgia and admitted to practice before the trial and appellate courts of this state. Nothing in this article shall prevent the city from appointing the city attorney to be the prosecuting attorney for the municipal court, so long as all other requirements under the law are met. (Ord. No. 2016-01 , 4-12-2016) Sec. 18-80. - Oath. In addition to the oaths prescribed in O.C.G.A. Chapter 3 of Title 45, the prosecuting attorney of the municipal court of the City of Springfield shall take and subscribe to the following oath: "I swear (or affirm) that I will well, faithfully, and impartially and without fear, favor, or affection discharge my duties as prosecuting attorney of the Municipal Court of the City of Springfield." (Ord. No. 2016-01 , 4-12-2016) Sec. 18-81. - Term of office. The prosecuting attorney for the municipal court of the City of Springfield shall serve a one year term of office which is automatically renewable. Reappointment of the prosecuting attorney upon renewal shall not be required. The city may, in its sole discretion, shorten the term of office of the prosecuting attorney at any time. (Ord. No. 2016-01 , 4-12-2016) Sec. 18-82. - Jurisdiction, duties, and authority. The office of prosecuting attorney of the municipal court of the City of Springfield shall have the duty and authority to represent the city as defined by the city charter and by state law, and particularly as described in O.C.G.A. § 15-18-96. (Ord. No. 2016-01 , 4-12-2016) Sec. 18-83. - Assistant prosecuting attorney. The prosecuting attorney of the municipal court of the City of Springfield may appoint one or more assistant prosecuting attorneys whose appointment shall be ratified by the city council before becoming an assistant prosecuting attorney for the municipal court. Such assistant prosecuting attorney shall be a member in good standing of the State Bar of Georgia or satisfy the provisions of the Third Year Practice Act, found in the O.C.G.A., § 15-18-22. (Ord. No. 2016-01 , 4-12-2016) Sec. 18-84. - Ratification. This article shall ratify all actions that have been taken by the persons acting in the positions of the office of the prosecuting attorney for the municipal court to date as authorized by the mayor and his council. (Ord. No. 2016-01 , 4-12-2016)

div.head: Chapter 20 - NUISANCES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-1 et seq.
Sec. 20-1. - Penalty. Unless stated otherwise, violations of this chapter are punishable as provided in section 1-7. Sec. 20-2. - Nuisance abatement. (a) The city is authorized pursuant to the police powers granted to it and its Charter to repair, close, or demolish buildings or structures in the manner provided in this section. (b) The provisions of this section shall also be applied to private property, when an accumulation of weeds, trash, junk, filth, and other unsanitary or unsafe conditions shall create a public health hazard or general nuisance to those persons residing in the vicinity. A finding by any governmental health department, health officer, or building inspector that such property is a health or safety hazard shall constitute prima facie evidence that said property is in violation of this section. (c) For purposes of this section, the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. § 41-2-8 shall have the same meaning for such words used herein. (d) The provisions of O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9(a) through (f) are hereby incorporated herein and made a part of this section. (e) The provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-10 and 41-2-11 insofar as such provisions are not inconsistent with O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9 as amended are hereby adopted and made a part hereof and the powers granted in O.C.G.A. § 41-2-11 to the public officer are hereby expressly adopted for the purpose of the public officer carrying out the duties pursuant to this section. (f) This section shall be construed and is intended to be read in a manner consistent with the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-7 through 41-2-16. ( Ord. No. 2009-01, 3-10-2009 )

div.head: Chapter 23 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
Chapter 26 - SOLID WASTE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; local solid waste plans, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-31.1; littering, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-40 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 26-1. - Penalty. Unless stated otherwise, violations of this chapter are punishable as provided in section 1-7. Sec. 26-2. - Littering in public places. It shall be unlawful for any person to drop, place, throw, dump, deposit or permit or cause to be dropped, placed, thrown, dumped, or deposited any trash, garbage, dead animals, cans, rubbish, paper cups, wastepaper, litter, brickbats, or any discarded material upon the roads, streets, lanes, or other rights-of-way in the city, or its parks, playgrounds, parking lots, schoolgrounds, church grounds, or any other location in said city visible from any place where the public is free to go. ( Ord. No. 04-74, 8-5-1974 ) State Law reference— Littering, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-40 et seq. Sec. 26-3. - Litter on private property. (a) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Garbage means putrescible solid waste, including all food waste and general household refuse, such as waste accumulations of animal or vegetable matter used or intended for use as food, including nonputrescible solid waste that attends the preparation, use, cooking, handling or storage of said matter, such as rags, glass, tin cans, paper, cloth, plastic materials and other similar items. Litter means manmade or man-used solid waste material, such as paper, glass, cardboard boxes, or cans. Rubbish means nonputrescible waste such as waste material from the construction, remodeling and repair operations on houses, commercial buildings and other structures, abandoned appliances and furniture, concrete, bricks, plaster, earth, lumber shavings, sawdust, crates, metal, rubber, and also nonputrescible industrial waste such as rejected building materials, rolls of paper and similar items. Trash, junk means all nonputrescible solid waste such as dust, leaves, yard clippings, tree branches, grass, straw, wood or metal as well as other similar materials normally accumulated in the care and maintenance of residential property or commercial property. Weeds, undergrowth means poison ivy, plants of obnoxious odors, and grasses causing hay fever, or other vegetation which serves as a breeding place for mosquitoes or refuge for snakes and rats or as a hiding place for filth and any growth that creates a fire or traffic hazard or a nuisance due to unsightliness. (b) Unlawful hazards. It shall be unlawful for all owners of lots or tracts of land in the city, whether occupied or unoccupied, to permit or allow garbage, litter, rubbish, filth, weeds, undergrowth, trash/junk and other offensive matter and material to accumulate and remain on the premises of any lot within the city limits, if such materials increase the hazards of fire, accidents, or other calamities or create an unsafe, unsanitary, or dangerous condition detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the residents of the city or if such conditions otherwise are inimical to the welfare of the residents of the city. ( Ord. No. 02-03, §§ 1, 2, 8-12-2003 ) Secs. 26-4—26-24. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 26-25. - Municipal jurisdiction. It shall be mandatory that all owners, occupants, tenants and lessees of residential buildings, offices or businesses, commercial buildings and premises and the same shall be required to accept such collection and removal services as it relates to the disposal of garbage, trash, rubbish and other debris within the municipal jurisdiction of the city. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(31), 4-22-2008 ) Sec. 26-26. - Nuisance. (a) The keeping of garbage in containers other than containers prescribed by this article or the keeping upon premises of garbage or yard waste which is allowed to become offensive and noisome, shall constitute a public nuisance and may be abated in the manner provided by law. (b) A separate violation shall be deemed committed each day during or upon which such unlawful accumulation continues. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(48), 4-22-2008 ) Sec. 26-27. - Illegal disposal of garbage, etc. (a) No person shall deposit garbage, trash or refuse on or bury in, any public easements or right-of-way, street, alley, sidewalk, or other public land, or any storm sewer, vacant or unoccupied lot, or any lake, stormwater ditch, creek or watercourse. (b) It shall be unlawful for any owner, occupant or lessee of any building, yard or lots of ground within the city to allow garbage, trash or refuse of any kind to accumulate or remain in the building, or upon the yard or lot, unless placed in a container as required by this division. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(47), 4-22-2008 ) Sec. 26-28. - Removal of solid waste or other debris. If a customer has not removed extra or nonconforming solid waste, hazardous waste or refuse within 48 hours after notification by the city, the city manager or designee may order such removal and all costs incurred shall be placed against the customer's utility account. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(49), 4-22-2008 ) Sec. 26-29. - Notification for collection. All occupants and persons in possession, charge or control of premises and places in or upon which garbage is created, accumulated or produced shall notify the city that collection of garbage from such places is required. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(32), 4-22-2008 ) Sec. 26-30. - Business and industries within the city. All businesses and industries located in the city shall place all the garbage and rubbish generated by them in authorized containers. All commercial bulk containers must have closefitting lids. All lids and side doors shall be kept closed by the users so the contents are covered at all times. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(33), 4-22-2008 ) Sec. 26-31. - Precollection. (a) All garbage and refuse shall be placed in plastic or paper bags with the tops securely tied and stored in solid waste containers authorized by the city. (b) Any solid waste that may injure or hamper a collector, such as, but not limited to, broken glass; light bulbs, razor blades, fluorescent, neon or other gas-filled tubes; or other potentially sharp or hazardous objects shall be securely wrapped so as to prevent puncture to the wrapping or solid waste container. (c) Private streets and other roads which are not dedicated city rights-of-way shall be fully accessible to the city's provider and equipment in order for collections to be made by the city. (d) If any authorized garbage container is obstructed in such a manner as to prohibit the automated collection vehicle from dumping the container, the container's contents will not be collected. Waste placed in containers other than authorized containers will not be collected. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(34), 4-22-2008 ) Sec. 26-32. - Authorized containers. Each residential dwelling or commercial unit that has individually metered water service will be provided one standard authorized rollaway garbage container by the city. Upon request, one additional garbage container may be delivered to a residential dwelling unit at an additional monthly charge. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(35), 4-22-2008 ) Sec. 26-33. - Loss or damage to authorized containers. (a) Authorized containers assigned to residential or commercial customers by the city are and shall remain property of the city's provider. (b) Damage to, loss, or removal of an authorized container assigned to a residential or commercial unit shall be the responsibility of the holder of the water account for the unit at the time such damage, loss, or removal is discovered by the city, and such holder of the water account or property owner (if no water account is noted) shall be liable for all costs associated with replacing the container unless the damage is determined to be caused by another party or the container is determined to be faulty. (c) Persons moving from one address in the city to another address in the city, or from the city to another locality, shall leave all authorized containers at the dwelling to which the containers have been assigned. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(36), 4-22-2008 ) Sec. 26-34. - Maintenance of authorized containers. (a) Authorized containers assigned shall be the responsibility of and kept and maintained by the occupants of such units in a clean and sanitary manner so as to prevent the breeding of flies, vermin, or vectors, or the release of odors. (b) Dumpsters and multifamily containers assigned to multifamily dwellings and mobile home parks shall be the responsibility of and maintained by the owner of such units and the manager of such units in a clean, disinfected, and sanitary manner so as to prevent the breeding of flies, vermin, or vectors, or the release of odors. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(37), 4-22-2008 ) Sec. 26-35. - Time of placement of residential solid waste for collection. (a) Authorized containers shall be placed in a location that is readily accessible to collection equipment, not to exceed two feet from the curb or edge of the traveled portion of the street or road and not to be located in a manner that will block the driveway or mailbox or otherwise inhibit proper servicing. All authorized containers shall be placed adjacent to the street or lane on which the property faces. Containers shall not, however be placed so as to interfere with vehicular or pedestrian traffic. (b) Garbage and trash shall be set out for collection entirely within fully closed authorized garbage containers and placed on the street abutting the residential or commercial unit for which the container was assigned, as near to the curb as possible, and far enough away from other containers, vehicles, utility lines and boxes, poles, mail-boxes, and other objects so as to facilitate collection by automated collection vehicles. (c) Such placement shall not restrict access to public sidewalks, pathways and bicycle paths. Where there is no curb, authorized containers shall be placed next to the edge of the road pavement in the same manner as if there were a curb. For proper automated collection, the authorized garbage container shall be placed in such a manner as to have sufficient clearance on each side so as to be accessible to the automated collections vehicle with the container handle facing away from the street or right-of-way. (d) All residents utilizing city collection or yard debris shall place such items on their premises behind the curbline, located so as to be easily accessible to street pickup, not to be placed over or next to fixed items such as fire hydrants, telephone or electrical boxes, mail boxes or anything that could be damaged by equipment or personnel picking up said items. The city will not be responsible for repairing or replacing any item removed or damaged which was placed curbside in such a manner that it appeared to be intended for removal or was not visible because it was mixed with other items placed curbside. (e) Residential solid waste shall be set out for collection as otherwise provided in this article not earlier than the day preceding the scheduled collection day and shall be removed from the curb no later than the day after the scheduled collection. (f) Authorized containers shall be removed from the street and stored on the side or rear of the dwelling to which it is assigned as soon as possible after collection. Alternative storage locations for trash carts may be permitted on a case-by-case basis upon approval by the zoning official. In such cases, a visual barrier shall be provided which keeps trash carts out of view from the public right-of-way to the maximum extent possible. In no instance shall containers be permitted to remain on the street after midnight of the day following the scheduled collection day. (g) No containers shall be stored on city easements or rights-of-way except for times specified for collections. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(38), 4-22-2008 ; Ord. No. 2017-01 , § 1, 3-14-2017) Sec. 26-36. - Collection assistance due to physical limitations. (a) The city manager or designee may visit any residence to determine if curbside placement of the authorized container is impossible due to physical limitations. A written verification by a medical doctor that the resident is unable to physically place garbage and trash at the curbside may be required. (b) Residences receiving assistance with the non-curbside service will utilize a collection point designated by the city's provider. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(39), 4-22-2008 ) Sec. 26-37. - Special service. Any person requesting special service, that is the collection of any items not otherwise provided for in this article, may arrange with the city for such service, upon payment in advance of the estimated cost if, in the opinion of the city manager, personnel and equipment are available to give such service. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(40), 4-22-2008 ) Sec. 26-38. - Scavenging. No person other than the owner or authorized collection personnel shall sift the contents of or remove anything from containers, boxes or bundles containing garbage or rubbish. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(41), 4-22-2008 ) Sec. 26-39. - Move-outs and evictions. (a) For rental properties, garbage, trash, or other solid waste originating from the property during the cleanup between tenants shall be the responsibility of the landlord and/or the property owner. Following an eviction, any property, trash, belongings, or other items shall be placed on some portion of the landlord's property, immediately behind the sidewalk or if there is no sidewalk, a minimum of five feet behind the curb or off the pavement, and shall not be located as to impede or obstruct or divert either pedestrian or vehicular traffic or the flow of surface water or block drains. (b) Any property, trash, belongings, or other items placed curbside following an eviction shall be removed within 48 hours of the physical eviction by the property owner. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(42), 4-22-2008 ) Sec. 26-40. - Building materials. The city shall not be responsible for collecting or hauling discarded building materials, dirt, broken concrete, bricks, rock or debris resulting from repairs, renovations, remodeling, or construction waste (e.g., cabinets, doors, windows, roofing debris, lumber, siding carpet and/or floor coverings and plumbing fixtures, including, but not limited to, sinks, bath tubs, shower stalls, toilets). Such material must be disposed of by the builder, property owner, or tenant. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(43), 4-22-2008 ) Sec. 26-41. - Prohibited materials. (a) Dead animals, tires, sewage, poisons, commercial medical waste, explosives, dangerous or corrosive chemicals, motor oil, yard debris (e.g., leaves, limbs, etc.) and bulky items such as air conditioners, furniture, or lumber shall not be placed in receptacles used for regular collection service or in the city's container. (b) No person shall dispose of any hypodermic syringe, needle, instrument or device used for injections, except when in compliance with state and federal regulations and as a minimum make this material completely incapable of reuse. Prior to disposal, such material shall be placed in an appropriate container and secured so as to prevent injury to collectors. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(44), 4-22-2008 ) Sec. 26-42. - Drainage of refuse. All refuse capable of holding liquids must be drained before being deposited in the city's containers. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(45), 4-22-2008 ) Sec. 26-43. - Civil penalties. Any person, business, entity, or organization violating this article shall be subject to a civil penalty of not less than $110.00, nor more than $550.00, for each violation. The accused violator of this article shall be deemed to be the person or entity in whose name the service is provided, the actual perpetrator of the violation, and/or the owner of the property, as applicable. The designated code enforcement officer is hereby authorized to issue notice of imposition of such civil penalty. Subject to the provisions of section 26-45, governing appeals, payment of the civil penalty shall be provided in the form of cash, money order, or certified check prior to the court date written on the notice of imposition of such civil penalty. The court date written on the notice of imposition of civil penalty shall be no sooner than 20 days after the date of the notice of imposition of civil penalty. The city attorney or his designee is hereby authorized to institute a proceeding in any court having jurisdiction thereof to collect such civil penalty. All civil penalties recovered pursuant to this subsection shall be deposited into a dedicated fund of the city. (Ord. No. 2016-02 , § 1, 7-12-2016; Ord. No. 2017-08 , § 1, 10-10-2017) Sec. 26-44. - Notice of imposition of civil penalty. Notice of imposition of a civil penalty for a violation of this article shall be accomplished by mailing the notice to the last known address of the person or entity in whose name the service is provided, the actual perpetrator of the violation, and/or the owner of the property, as applicable. Notice of imposition of a civil penalty for violation of this article shall specify the nature of the violation, shall specify the section and (if applicable) subsection which the accused violator is alleged to have violated, shall specify the payment amount due, shall specify that payment is to be provided in cash, money order, or certified check, shall specify the court date on which the accused violator is scheduled to appear, and shall specify that the accused violator has the right to appeal the imposition of the civil penalty to the designated code enforcement officer. (Ord. No. 2016-02 , § 1, 7-12-2016; Ord. No. 2017-08 , § 1, 10-10-2017) Sec. 26-45. - Appeal. Any person, business, entity, or organization aggrieved by a civil penalty imposed pursuant to this article shall have the right to appeal to the designated code enforcement officer. The appeal shall be accomplished by providing a document, a form which will be made available by the city, titled "Notice of Appeal" on which the accused violator identifies the basis for the appeal and attaches or references the notice of civil penalty. To be effective, any notice of appeal filed pursuant to this article must be received no later than five days prior to the court date on which the accused violator is scheduled to appear. Failure to submit a notice of appeal within the required time frame shall constitute a waiver of the accused violator's right to appeal, and the accused violator shall appear in court or pay the penalty prior to the scheduled court date. Upon receipt of a timely notice of appeal, the designated code enforcement officer shall determine whether the accused violator violated this article, and based on that determination, is authorized to, in his/her sole discretion, confirm, modify or waive such civil penalty. The designated code enforcement officer's determination shall be in writing and provided to the accused violator. If the accused violator is dissatisfied with the designated code enforcement officer's determination, the accused violator may dispute the violation in the municipal court of the City of Springfield on the scheduled court date. (Ord. No. 2016-02 , § 1, 7-12-2016; Ord. No. 2017-08 , § 1, 10-10-2017) Secs. 26-46—26-72. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - COLLECTORS
Sec. 26-73. - Contracts with independent solid waste providers. In order for the city to provide adequate service to the citizens of the city for the collection, removal and disposal of refuse accumulated, the city may enter into a contract with an independent contractor, either private or another municipal corporate entity, for such services. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(70), 4-22-2008 ) Sec. 26-74. - Contract price. The city council may negotiate with an independent contractor or another municipal corporate entity the terms, conditions and consideration to be paid for the services sought under such a contract; and it shall be presumed that any consideration agreed upon between the city and such independent contractor or municipal corporate entity shall be in the best interest and welfare of the citizens of this city. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(71), 4-22-2008 ) Secs. 26-75—26-91. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - RATES AND CHARGES
Sec. 26-92. - Rates. (a) Fees for collection of garbage and yard waste shall be those as established by resolution of the city council, and shall be published in the office of the city hall where utility bills may be paid. (b) Rates will be subject to periodic review and adjusted by the city council by separate resolution as necessary to ensure adequate cost recovery for operation of the sanitary municipal solid waste system. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(90), 4-22-2008 ) Sec. 26-93. - Billing. Owners or occupants of premises receiving such service shall be billed for refuse collection and disposal charges in the same manner and at the same time as invoices for water are billed. The charges for solid waste collection and water service shall appear on the same bill with each charge substantiated. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(91), 4-22-2008 ) Sec. 26-94. - Nonpayment of fees. Any person failing or refusing to pay the monthly solid waste bill or other related charges provided for in this article after having been duly billed by the city, shall be guilty of a violation of this article, and all solid waste services and water service provided by the city to the premises for which the monthly charges are past due may be terminated by the city. ( Ord. No. 2008-06, § 1(92), 4-22-2008 )

div.head: Chapter 29 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Municipal street systems generally, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-90 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 29-1. - Penalty. Unless stated otherwise, violations of this chapter are punishable as provided in section 1-7. Secs. 29-2—29-19. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - OBSTRUCTIONS AND ENCROACHMENTS
Sec. 29-20. - Violation of article deemed nuisance. Any violation of this article and any material part thereof shall be deemed a nuisance per se, and the city council shall, upon ten days' written notice to any person found in violation thereof, proceed to abate said nuisance. ( Ord. No. 01-61, § V, 11-27-1961 ) Sec. 29-21. - Open air markets. No person shall conduct, maintain or operate an open air market upon the sidewalks or streets in this city, and shall not use any part of the system of streets and sidewalks for the purpose of display of merchandise for sale, except with the written permission of the city council. ( Ord. No. 01-61, § I, 11-27-1961 ) Sec. 29-22. - Awnings, sheds or marquees. No person shall erect, construct or maintain any shed, awning or marquee so that the same shall extend or project over the sidewalks of the city, except with the written permission of the city council, and then only in such instances where there is a clearance of at least seven feet between the sidewalk and such shed, awning or marquee, and provided the same is suspended from a building with adequate support to hold the same so that no structure, pillar, post or other device shall be required to be erected upon the sidewalk, within the grass plots between the sidewalks or within the streets for the purpose of supporting such structure. ( Ord. No. 01-61, § II, 11-27-1961 ) Sec. 29-23. - Temporary structures. No person shall at any time erect any temporary or permanent structure within 20 feet of a fire plug and across the property line between the abutting landowner and the sidewalk. ( Ord. No. 01-61, § III, 11-27-1961 ) Sec. 29-24. - Curb service enterprises near fire hydrants. No person shall conduct a curb service enterprise for delivery or servicing to customers where such service is within 20 feet of a fire hydrant. This section does not apply to normal customer delivery from stores to properly parked vehicles where such vehicles are parked in a legal parking area. ( Ord. No. 01-61, § IV, 11-27-1961 )

div.head: Chapter 32 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Traffic generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 et seq.; powers of local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-370 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 32-1. - Penalty. Unless stated otherwise, violations of this chapter are punishable as provided in section 1-7. Sec. 32-2. - State traffic laws adopted. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-372 through 40-6-376, O.C.G.A. title 40, ch. 6 (O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.) and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of this the city, with like effect as if recited herein. Violations of this section are an offense. ( Ord. No. 2008-08, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-2008 ) Sec. 32-3. - Motorized carts. (a) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Motorized cart, electric and gasoline, means powered pleasure carts, commonly known as golf carts. These carts have not less than three wheels and cannot be operated more than 20 miles per hour. (b) Purpose and intent. The purpose of this section is to protect, maintain, and enhance health, safety, and general welfare of present and future citizens of the city. It has come to the attention of the mayor and council that the unregulated use of motorized carts on city streets creates a potential traffic hazard for other vehicular traffic as well as a danger to the occupants of motorized carts. Therefore, the intent of this chapter is to regulate the use of motorized carts within the corporate limits of the city as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 40-6-331. (c) Operations and limitations. (1) Motorized carts may be operated within the corporate limits of the city by: a. Those persons who have a valid motor vehicle driver's license and operate in conformity with all restrictions of state law. (2) All operators of motorized carts shall abide by all traffic regulations applicable to vehicular traffic. (3) Motorized carts cannot be operated on the sidewalks of Laurel Street, except for approved locations as indicated on the Springfield Golf Cart Map. If a cart is being operated on the sidewalk the cart must give right-of-way to pedestrian traffic, except those adjacent to the owner's property. (4) Carts will not be permitted in city parks. (5) Motorized carts shall be operated during daylight hours only. (6) Motorized carts may not traverse streets and highways under the jurisdiction of the state department of transportation. Motorized carts may cross at the approved crossing only. The state department of transportation approved crossing is located at the intersection of Laurel Street at Second Street. (7) Motorized carts commonly known as go-carts or all-terrain vehicles (ATV) may not be legally operated upon city streets. (8) The city will issue permits for the carts. a. The requirements are that the owner must supply a valid license for each driver that will be operating the cart. Each and every driver must be on the permit before operating the cart. b. The owner will sign acknowledging that he/she understands this section and will abide by same. c. The owner will solely be responsible for any and all liability of such cart and shall provide proof of liability insurance. d. The permit cost will be $25.00, which will consist of a $15.00 permit fee, and a $10.00 administrative fee. Two permit stickers to be affixed on each side of the cart by the police department. e. Permits will expire exactly five years from the issue date. f. These carts will not be allowed on the following city streets: 1. Stillwell Road (except for the crossing at Ash Street). 2. Laurel Street (except for the crossing at Second (2nd) Street). g. The cart must have adequate seating for all passengers; there will be no standing, hanging off of or overloading the capacity of the cart. (d) Exceptions. (1) Nothing in this section shall apply to any self-propelled, two-wheeled vehicle. (2) Nothing in this section shall apply to motorized carts operated by the city. (e) Enforcement. The city police department shall be charged with enforcement of this section. The department will have the authority to revoke a permit upon knowledge that a cart has no insurance. (f) Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this section shall be punished by a fine for the first offense of not less than $100.00, for the second offense $250.00 and for a third offense $500.00. The permit for the cart will be suspended upon the third offense within a five-year period. ( Ord. No. 01-03, §§ I—III, V—VII, 6-24-2003 ; Ord. No. 2012-01 , §§ 1—6, 2-14-2012) Sec. 32-4. - Skateboards. (a) For purpose of this section the term "skateboard or other like instruments" shall be deemed to refer to any nonmotorized instrument used to transport a person by means of wheels or rollers, propelled solely by the force of its rider. The term "skateboard" shall not include bicycles or other geared, nonmotorized transports defined elsewhere in this Code. (b) No person shall use, operate or permit the use or operation of any skateboard or other like instrument on Highway 21/Laurel Street or any sidewalk, parking lot or other public place immediately adjacent to Highway 21/Laurel Street. No person shall use, operate or permit the use or operation of any skateboard or other like instrument on any other street, sidewalk, parking lot or other public place within the city limits of the city within 50 feet of any organized public gathering or if such use is likely to produce injury to person or property. (c) Every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this section shall be punished by a fine of not more than $25.00 or by impoundment of the violator's skateboard for a period not to exceed 30 days or by any combination thereof. ( Ord. No. 02-90, §§ 1—3, 7-2-1990 ) Sec. 32-5. - Load limits. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to drive, cause, or permit any vehicle weighing in excess of five tons (10,000 lbs.) to cross, travel on, or be on any of the following streets in said city: All streets in the Cherokee Park subdivision (except border streets and roads, namely McCall Road and that road which crosses its northwest corner, sometimes known as the Old Guyton Road): (1) Third (3rd) Street, from Oak Street to Maple Street. (2) Maple Street, from Third Street to Fourth Street. (3) Fourth (4th) Street, from Oak Street to Ash Street. (4) First Street Extension in Southwest Springfield. (b) Vehicles of more than 2½-ton load rating shall, when loaded, be presumed to weigh more than five tons. (c) Any person found to be in violation of this section shall be punished by a fine of not more than $100.00 and a sentence of ten days in jail, either one or both. ( Ord. No. 01-79, 3-5-1979 ) Secs. 32-6—32-28. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING
Sec. 32-29. - Violations and penalties. (a) Any person accused of the violation of this article may settle or compromise the claim against him for such illegal parking by paying to the municipality the sum of $2.00 which may be done within 24 hours of the time such alleged offense was committed. Such payment may be made at the police station, and a receipt shall be issued for all money so received. The money shall be promptly turned over to the city clerk to be credited to the general fund. (b) Upon settlement of the charge, if done within the time specified, the members of the police department are hereby authorized to refrain from instituting a prosecution for the alleged offense involved. (c) Any car left parked in violation of this article for a period in excess of 24 hours or under such conditions that the police department shall deem a distinct hazard to traffic shall be removed from the street by the chief of police or members of the police department who shall have the authority to have such automobile towed away by a commercial repair or storage garage service to be stored in a safe place until claimed by the owner or operator. The owner or operator of such car upon the payment of the towing charges and the storage charges, shall have the car restored to him. (d) Every person failing to compromise or settle the charges for overtime parking by paying the specified fee to the city clerk or any person violating any other section of this article shall be subject to citation by the police department and prosecution for the alleged offense involved. Upon conviction in the police court in the city for such violation, the defendant shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $10.00 or imprisoned for not to more than three days in the jail of the city, either or both at the discretion of said court. (e) The chief of police or any other persons authorized by the mayor and council shall cause signs to be posted in all areas where parking is limited indicating such limitations. ( Ord. No. 01-71, §§ VI—VIII, 5-3-1971 ) Sec. 32-30. - Prohibited on specific streets. It shall be unlawful for any person during the hours of the day from 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. to park, leave, keep or to allow to stand or remain standing any motor vehicle or motor-propelled conveyance on Laurel Street or on Jefferson Street in said city for any time in excess of the limit of time at the specified locations set forth in the following sections, to wit: (1) At any point on the eastern side of Laurel Street between Rabun Street on the north and Stillwell Road on the south for a period of time in excess of two hours. (2) At any point on the western side of Laurel Street between Jackson Street on the North and Jefferson Street on the south and between Crawford Street on the north and Third Street on the south for a period of time in excess of two hours. (3) At any point on the western side of Laurel Street between Jefferson Street on the north and Crawford Street on the south for a period of time in excess of one hour. (4) At any point on the northern and/or southern side of Jefferson Street between Pine Street on the east and the property of the Savannah and Atlanta Railway on the west for a period of time in excess of three hours. ( Ord. No. 01-71, §§ I—V, 5-3-1971 )

div.head: Chapter 35 - UTILITIES
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 35-1. - Penalty. Unless stated otherwise, violations of this chapter are punishable as provided in section 1-7. Secs. 35-2—35-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - WATER AND SEWER CHARGES DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 35-21. - Water meter installation fee. The water meter installation fee shall be as established by the city. ( Ord. of 10-5-1959 ) Sec. 35-22. - Service deposits. The water and sewer service deposit shall be as established by the city. ( Ord. No. 03-85, 9-10-1985 ) Sec. 35-23. - Water connection impact fee. There is hereby established a waterline connection impact fee. Such fee shall be as established by the city. ( Ord. No. 02-74, 5-7-1974 ; Ord. of 8-3-1987 ; Ord. No. 01-93, 3-2-1993 ) Sec. 35-24. - User rates. The monthly charges for water and/or sewer service shall be as established by the city. ( Ord. of 3-2-1993 ; Ord. No. 02-96, 4-9-1996 ) Secs. 35-25—35-51. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - SEWER IMPACT FEES[1]
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Georgia Development Impact Fee Act, O.C.G.A. § 36-71-1 et seq.
Sec. 35-52. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Capital improvement shall be as defined in O.C.G.A. § 36-71-2(1). City manager means the city official designated to carry out the administration of this article. Fee payer shall be as defined in O.C.G.A. § 36-71-2(1) is a person applying for connection to the city's sewer system. Public facility means wastewater collection, treatment and disposal facilities. Service area means a geographic area defined by the city in which a defined set of public facilities provide service to development within the area. Said areas shall be designated on the basis of sound planning or engineering principles or both. Sewer system means the city's sewer facilities. ( Ord. No. 2008-05, § 5, 3-11-2008 ) Sec. 35-53. - Rules of construction. For the purposes of administration and enforcement of this article, unless otherwise stated in this article, the following rules of construction shall apply to the text of this article. The term "includes" shall not limit a term to the specific example but is intended to extend its meaning to all other instances or circumstances of like character. ( Ord. No. 2008-05, § 4, 3-11-2008 ) Sec. 35-54. - Legislative findings. The city council finds, determines and declares that: (1) The city must expand its sewer facilities in order to maintain current standards of public health if new development is to be accommodated without decreasing current standards of public health. (2) The state, through O.C.G.A. title 36, ch. 71 (O.C.G.A § 36-71-1 et seq.), has permitted municipalities to enact impact fees. (3) The imposition of impact fees is one of the preferred methods of ensuring that development bears a proportionate share of the cost of sewer facilities necessary to accommodate such development and this must be done in order to promote and protect the public health, safety and welfare. (4) Connecting to the city's sewer systems will create the need for the construction, equipping, or expansion of the water and sewer facilities. (5) The fees established by this division are derived from, are based upon, and do not exceed the costs of providing additional sewer facilities necessitated by the connection to the city's sewer system including any state or federal mandates. (6) The report entitled, "City of Springfield, Georgia, Sanitary Sewer Impact Fee Methodology," dated August 2007, and incorporated herein, sets forth a reasonable methodology and analysis for the determination of the impact of new development on the need for and costs for additional sewer facilities in the city. The methodology is recorded on file in the office of the city council. ( Ord. No. 2008-05, § 1, 3-11-2008 ) Sec. 35-55. - Intent and purposes. (a) This division is intended to assist the implementation of the city with the 2007 through 2012 capital improvements program. (b) The purpose of this division is to ensure that new development bears a proportionate share of the cost of capital expenditures necessary to provide sewer facilities in the city or in the areas that the city serves. ( Ord. No. 2008-05, § 3, 3-11-2008 ) Sec. 35-56. - Applicability. This division shall apply in the unincorporated areas of the county served by the city with sewer systems. ( Ord. No. 2008-05, § 2, 3-11-2008 ) Sec. 35-57. - Compliance with and incorporation of state law. This division shall comply with the provisions of the Georgia Development Impact Fee Act (O.C.G.A. § 36-71-1 et seq.). The provisions of such act are hereby adopted into this division and made a part hereof. In the event any portion of this division is in conflict with such act then in that event such act shall control. ( Ord. No. 2008-05, § 18, 3-11-2008 ) Sec. 35-58. - Imposition of sewer facilities impact fee. (a) Any person who seeks to connect to the city sewer system is hereby required to pay a sewer facilities impact fee in the manner and amount set forth in this division. (b) Funds withdrawn from these accounts must be used in accordance with the provisions of state law. ( Ord. No. 2008-05, § 6, 3-11-2008 ) Sec. 35-59. - Computation of the amount of sewer facilities impact fee. (a) The amount of the sewer facilities impact fee is determined by estimated usage based upon accepted studies for various types of users which is recorded on file in the office of the city council. (b) In the case of change of principal land use, redevelopment or expansion or modification of an existing land use which requires a new, replacement, or additional connection to the city's water and/or sewer system, the impact fee shall be based upon the difference of the old user's fee and the new user's fee. (c) Any person may request an individual assessment of development impact fees at the option of the applicant for development approval under guidelines established in this division. (d) A developer may receive a certification of the development impact fee schedule or individual assessment for a project which shall establish the development impact fees for a period of 180 days from the date of the certification. ( Ord. No. 2008-05, § 7, 3-11-2008 ) Sec. 35-60. - Payment of fees. (a) The fee payer shall pay the sewer facilities impact fees required by this division to the city's utility billing office prior to the issuance of any city building permit or as provided by state law. (b) All funds collected shall be properly identified and transferred for deposit to the appropriate sewer impact fee fund to be held in separate accounts as determined in section 35-62 and used solely for the purpose specified in this division or as provided by state law. ( Ord. No. 2008-05, § 8, 3-11-2008 ) Sec. 35-61. - Sewer facilities impact fee trust fund established. There is hereby established a separate sewer facilities impact fee trust fund account which shall be governed and managed in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 36-71-8, and shall be known as the sewer impact account. ( Ord. No. 2008-05, § 9, 3-11-2008 ) Sec. 35-62. - Use of funds. (a) Funds collected from sewer impact fees shall be used solely for the purpose of acquiring, equipping, and/or making capital improvements to sewer facilities under the jurisdiction of the city, and shall not be used for maintenance of operations. (b) Funds from the sewer impact fee account shall only be used for sewer facilities purposes. (c) In the event bonds, loans or other similar debt instruments are utilized for improving and/or upgrading sewer facilities for which sewer impact fees are expended, impact fees may be used with the approval of the city council, to pay debt on such bonds, loans or similar debt instruments to the extent that such facilities provided are the type described in subsection (a) of this section. (d) On an annual basis, the city manager shall present to the city council a proposed capital improvements program for sewer facilities, assigning funds from the sewer impact funds to specific sewer facilities improvements projects and related expenses. Monies, including any accrued interest, not assigned in any fiscal period shall be retained in the same sewer impact funds until the next fiscal period, except as provided by the refund provisions of this division. (e) Funds may be used to provide refunds as described in section 35-63. ( Ord. No. 2008-05, § 10, 3-11-2008 ) Sec. 35-63. - Refund of fees paid. All refunds of fees shall be in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 36-71-9. (1) Any funds not encumbered by the end of the calendar quarter immediately following six years from the date the sewer impact fees were paid, shall upon application by the fee payer, be returned to the city council within 90 days of the expiration period of the six-year period. (2) When the right to a refund exists, as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 34-71-9, due to failure to encumber development impact fees, the city shall provide written notice of entitlement to a refund to the fee payer who paid the development impact fees at the address shown on the application for development approval or to a successor in interest who has given notice to the city of a transfer or assignment of the right or entitlement to a refund and who had provided a mailing address. Such notice shall also be published within 30 days after the expiration of the six-year period after the date that the impact fees were collected and shall contain the heading, "Notice of Entitlement to Impact Fee Refund." (3) All refunds shall be made to the fee payer within 60 days after it is determined by the city that a sufficient proof or claim for a refund has been made. ( Ord. No. 2008-05, § 11, 3-11-2008 ) Sec. 35-64. - Exemptions and credits. (a) The following shall be exempted from payment of any impact fees: (1) The installation of a replacement mobile home on a lot or other such site when a sewer impact fee for such mobile home use had previously been paid pursuant to this division or where a mobile home legally existed prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived. (2) All claims for exemptions must be made at the time of application for a building permit or other appropriate city permits. Any claim not so made shall be deemed waived. (b) Credits. (1) Sewer facilities capital improvements may be offered by the fee payer as total or partial payment of the required impact fee. The fee payer may request a sewer facilities impact credit in writing to the city manager. If the city manager finds the offer to be acceptable, the offer shall be presented to the city council for final approval, the credit shall be determined and provided in the following manner: a. Credit for the dedication of land shall be valued at 100 percent of the most recent assessed value by the county assessor's office or by fair market value established by a private appraiser acceptable to the city. b. Applications for credit for construction of sewer facilities improvements shall submit acceptable engineering drawings, specifications and construction cost estimates to the city manager. The city manager shall turn said information over the city engineer for review and recommendations to the city manager. If the amount of credit created by such construction, funding or contribution is in excess of the development impact fees that would have been paid for the project, the developer shall be reimbursed for such excess construction, funding, or contribution from development impact fees paid by other development located in the service area which is benefited by such improvements. c. Except as provided in subsection (b)(1)b, credit against impact fees otherwise due shall not be provided until: 1. The construction is completed, inspected and accepted by the city; or 2. An acceptable performance bond is approved and received by the city manager. d. If the sewer facilities construction project is not constructed within one calendar year of the acceptance of the offer by the city council, the offer of credit shall be revoked with either the performance bond paying for such improvements or the immediate payment of the appropriate sewer impact fees in accordance with section 35-60. (2) Any claim for credit must be made no later than the time of application for a building permit. Any claim not so made shall be deemed waived. (3) Credits shall not be transferred from one project or development to another without the approval of the city council. (4) Credits shall not be transferable from one component of the sewer facilities impact fee to another. (5) In the event a building permit is abandoned, credit shall be given for the present value of the impact fees against future impact fees for the same parcel of land. (6) The city manager shall provide the applicant for credit a letter setting forth the dollar amount of credit, the sewer impact fee comment for which the credit shall apply, and the identification of the specific project being credited. The applicant must sign said letter indicating his agreement with the terms of the letter and return such signed and notarized document within 30 days or the credit shall be nullified. ( Ord. No. 2008-05, § 12, 3-11-2008 ) Sec. 35-65. - Review of fee schedule. The impact fees contained in section 35-59 shall be reviewed by the city council on an annual basis in conjunction with the implementation of the city's capital improvements program. The development impact fee advisory committee shall review all proposed amendments and make a recommendation to the city council before final enactment. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 36-71-6, the city shall conduct two public hearings prior to the final adoption of any amendments. ( Ord. No. 2008-05, § 13, 3-11-2008 ) Sec. 35-66. - Annual audit process. As a part of the city's annual audit process, the city shall prepare an annual report describing the amount of any development impact fees collected, encumbered, and used during the preceding year by category of public facility and service area. ( Ord. No. 2008-05, § 14, 3-11-2008 ) Sec. 35-67. - Appeals. Any fee payer who desires to appeal the payment to the city or other administrative actions regarding this division, may appeal, to city council, such action upon written notice to the city council within 30 days after the impact fee has been paid to the city. Any action taken upon the appeal shall be deemed final. ( Ord. No. 2008-05, § 15, 3-11-2008 ) Secs. 35-68—35-92. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 35-93. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under EPA approval laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter. Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of buildings and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five feet outside the inner face of the building wall. Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal, also called the house connection or service connection. Combined sewer means a sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage. Customer means every person who is responsible for contracting, expressly or implicitly, with the city in obtaining, having, or using sewer connections with, or sewer taps to, the sewer system of the city and in obtaining, having, or using water and other related services furnished by the city for the purpose of disposing of wastewater and sewage through said system. Said terms shall include the occupants of each unit of a multiple-family dwelling unit building as a separate and distinct customer. Easement means an acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others. Floatable oil means oil, fat, or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. A wastewater shall be considered free of floatable oil if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection system. Flush toilet means the common sanitary flush commode in general use for the disposal of human excrement. Garbage means the animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking, and serving of foods. Health officer means the director of the county board of health or other person designated by the board of commissioners and their duly appointed assistants. Industrial wastes means the wastewater from industrial processes as distinct from domestic or sanitary wastes. Infiltration/inflow means groundwater and surface water which leaks into the sewers through cracked pipes, joints, manholes, or other openings. May is permissive (see Shall ). Municipality means the governmental body having jurisdiction over the maintenance and operations of the water and sanitary sewer system within the City of Springfield and adjacent areas of Effingham County. Natural outlet means any outlet, including storm sewers and combined sewer overflows, into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake, or other body or surface of groundwater. Normal wastewater means wastewater discharged into the sanitary sewers in which the average concentration of total suspended solids is not more than 350 milligrams per liter (mg/l), BODs is not more than 300 mg/l, total phosphorous is not more than 15 mg/l, total Kjeldahl nitrogen is not more than 20 mg/l, and the total flow is not more than 25,000 gallons per day. Person means any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation, or group. pH means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration. Pit privy means a shored, vertical pit in the earth completely covered with a flytight slab on which is securely located a flytight riser covered with hinged flytight seat and lid. Properly-shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch in any dimension. Public sewer means a common sewer controlled by a governmental agency or public utility. Sanitary sewer means a sewer that carries liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions together with minor quantities of groundwater, stormwater, and surface water that are not intentionally admitted. Septic tank means a subsurface, impervious tank designed to temporarily retain sewage or similar waterborne wastes together with: (1) A sewer line constructed with solid pipe, with joints sealed, connecting the impervious tank with a plumbing stub out; and (2) A subsurface system of trenches, piping, and other materials constructed to drain the clarified discharge from the tank and distribute it underground to be absorbed or filtered. Sewage is the spent water of a community. The equivalent term is "wastewater." Sewage works (sewerage) means all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating, and disposing of sewage. Sewer means a pipe or conduit that carries wastewater. Shall is mandatory. See May. Slug means any discharge of water or wastewater which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than 15 minutes more than five times the average 24-hour concentration of flows during normal operation and shall adversely affect the collection system and/or performance of the wastewater facilities. Storm drain , storm sewer means a drain or sewer for conveying water, groundwater, subsurface water, or unpolluted water from any source and excluding sewage and industrial wastes other than unpolluted cooling water. Superintendent means the utilities superintendent or his authorized deputy, agent or representative. Suspended solids means total suspended matter that either floats on the surface of, or is in suspension in, water, wastewater, or other liquids, and that is removable by laboratory filtration as approved by the EPA and referred to as nonfilterable residue. Unpolluted water means water of a quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect or water that would not cause a violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefited by discharge to the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided. Wastewater means the spent water of a community. From the standpoint of source, it may be a combination of the liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions, together with any groundwater, surface water, and stormwater that may be present. Wastewater facilities means the structures, equipment, and processes required to collect, carry away, and treat domestic and industrial wastes and dispose of the effluent. Watercourse means a natural or artificial channel for the passage of water either continuously or intermittently. ( Ord. of 4-18-1988, art. 2 ) Sec. 35-94. - Use of public sewers required. (a) All premises shall be provided, by the owner thereof, with at least one toilet. All toilets shall be kept clean and in a sanitary working condition. (b) No person shall dispose of human excrement except in a toilet. (c) It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any wastewater or other polluted waters, including septic tank effluent or cesspool overflow, to any open drain or well-penetrating, water-bearing formation, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this article. (d) Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of wastewater. (e) The owners of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes situated within the city jurisdiction and abutting on any street, alley, or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public sanitary sewer of the city, is hereby required at the owners' expense to install suitable toilet facilities herein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this article, within 30 days after date of official notice to do so, provided that said public sewer is within 100 feet of the property line. (f) All sinks, dishwashing machines, lavatories, basins, shower baths, bathtubs, laundry tubs, washing machines, and similar plumbing fixtures or appliances shall be connected to the public sewer; provided, that where no sewer is available, septic tanks or other private subsurface disposal facilities approved by the health officer may be used. ( Ord. of 4-18-1988, art. 3 ) Sec. 35-95. - Private wastewater disposal. (a) Where a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of 35-94, the building sewer shall be connected to a private wastewater disposal system complying with the provisions of the city and the state department of human resources. (b) Septic tanks shall be constructed, repaired, altered, enlarged and maintained in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the health officer. Septic tanks shall be maintained in sanitary working order. (c) No person shall construct, repair, alter, or enlarge any septic tank unless he shall hold a valid permit for such work issued by the health officer. The health officer may withhold the issuance of such a permit pending the inspection and approval by the health officer of the site and location of the proposed work. Before any septic tank or any part thereof may be covered after it has been constructed, repaired, altered, or enlarged, it shall be inspected and approved by the health officer. (d) The type, capacities, location, and layout of a private wastewater disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of the department of human resources of the state. No permit shall be issued for any private wastewater disposal system employing subsurface soil absorptions facilities where the area of the lot is less than 30,000 square feet without public water and less than 10,000 square feet with public water. No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet. (e) No septic tank or other subsurface disposal facility shall be installed where a public sewer is accessible to the premises involved, nor in any place where the health officer deems the use of same to be a menace to human health or well-being. (f) At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private wastewater disposal system, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer within 60 days after notice. Any septic tanks, cesspools, and similar private wastewater disposal facilities shall then be cleaned of sludge and filled with suitable material. (g) The owner shall operate and maintain the private wastewater disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the city. (h) No subsurface disposal facilities shall be installed in any place where the health officer deems the use of such facilities to be a menace to human health or well-being. (i) Every flush toilet shall be connected to a public sewer where available or to a septic tank. Flush toilets shall be provided at all times with sufficient running water under pressure to flush the toilet clean after each use. (j) No pit privy shall be installed in the following locations: (1) Where a public sewer is accessible to the premises involved; (2) In areas where the health officer deems the use of pit privies to constitute a nuisance or menace to the public health; (3) Where a pit privy may pollute any water supply; or (4) Where the use of pit privies is not in keeping with the standards of sanitation in adjacent areas. (k) Discharge of septic tanks in sewer system. (1) Restricted. It shall be unlawful to empty, dump, throw or otherwise ischarge, into any manhole, catchbasin or other opening, into the city sewer system, or any system connected with and discharging into the sewer system, the contents of any septic tank, sludge, sewage, or other similar matter or material, except as provided in subsection (k)(2) of this section. (2) Permits. The superintendent is hereby authorized to grant permits to discharge the contents of septic tanks at locations specified by the superintendent and under his supervision.
